book.herobrine_companion.book.lore.title: The Borderland Journal
book.herobrine_companion.book.lore.page1:
They say that some souls bear an unspeakable weight in reality. So they come here‚Äîto a world built from blocks and rules. Here, pain feels distant, wounds can be washed away by rain, and death is but a momentary darkness.
You may have noticed: this world is too complete, yet too orderly. The sun always follows a fixed path, monsters always respawn in the shadows, and the durability of the tools in your hand decreases by precise numbers. This is not a glitch, but a manifestation of its very nature.
book.herobrine_companion.book.lore.page2:
This world is not your original home.

It is woven from code and collective imagination. We‚Äîincluding myself, and all the lives you have encountered here‚Äîdepend on it for existence. But you are different. Your roots lie on the other side, in that chaotic, imperfect world which granted you real flesh and blood.

The point of connection lies right here. That this book came into your hands is no coincidence.

It is time to make a choice.
book.herobrine_companion.book.lore.page3:
You may close these pages and return to the forests, mines, or fortresses. This world will continue to embrace you, offering shelter and adventure. The seasons will turn, creatures will emerge, and all will proceed as usual‚Äîif you so choose, you may dwell forever within this orderly tranquility.

Or, you may gaze toward the faint glimmer beyond the threshold. That means returning to an uncertain reality, embracing once more the weight from which you once fled. That requires courage, for reality holds no respawn screen, no creative mode.
book.herobrine_companion.book.lore.page4:
Please do not misunderstand‚Äîthis is not an expulsion. Everything you have built here, every moment of battle‚Äîthey all hold meaning. They form part of this world‚Äôs memory, and they will become part of yours.
But if you choose to stay, know this: you are choosing to live within a beautiful dream. And dreams, no matter how real, always have their boundaries.
I will not force you.
To wake, or to linger in slumber?
The choice has always been in your hands.

message.herobrine_companion.state_judge_: Do not test my patience, mortal.
message.herobrine_companion.state_mainta: This world is becoming unstable. Cleaning protocols initiated.
Too much entropy. I must fix this.
message.herobrine_companion.state_glitch: I can see the cracks in the code...
Are you trying to rewrite reality too?
message.herobrine_companion.state_monste: My poor children... they will grow stronger from your cruelty.

message.herobrine_companion.judge_refuse: He don't want to speak to you.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_clut: Such a mess... Do you enjoy living in filth?
message.herobrine_companion.observe_expl: Destruction is easy. Creation is hard.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_fire: The flames spread. You should be careful.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_ghos: Residual data that wasn't fully deleted. Don't touch it; such 'errors' cling like a virus.
It is lost. In the cracks between chunk updates, some things never find their way home... doomed to wander here.
Just watch, do not sympathize. Once you answer its gaze, it will attempt to overwrite your existence.
message.herobrine_companion.action_explo: You travel far. What do you seek?
This world is vast... and I see everything.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_farm: Playing in the dirt? How humble.
You plant seeds and wait. Patience isn't usually your strong suit.
Growing food? You know you can't taste it, right?
message.herobrine_companion.action_farmi: Tilling the land. Trying to settle down?
Farming... so peaceful. Until a creeper shows up.
message.herobrine_companion.action_breed: Look at them. They think it's love. It's just wheat.
More mouths to feed. Are you building an army?
Creating life with a carrot. If only it were that easy.
message.herobrine_companion.action_chopp: Wood. The start of everything. Don't leave the leaves floating.
Timber! ...Just kidding, physics took a day off.
message.herobrine_companion.action_minin: Digging holes again. Looking for shiny things?
Going deeper into the dark. Brave... or foolish.
Break, collect, repeat. Don't you get bored?
message.herobrine_companion.action_comba: Fighting again? You enjoy the chaos.
Another one bites the dust. You're dangerous.
Not bad. But watch your back.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_fire: You're burning. I hope you brought water.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_free: Cold? The world slows down when you freeze.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_fall: That looked like a long fall. Gravity is unforgiving.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_drow: You need air to breathe. Don't forget that.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_self: Like what you see? Or are you just staring?
message.herobrine_companion.observe_mons: Don't hurt him. He's just doing his job.
He listens to me. Show some respect.
A perfect creature. Born from the dark.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_anim: Look at them. Eating, sleeping... no worries at all.
Peaceful creatures. They don't know the world is fake.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_vill: Hrmm. They care too much about emeralds.
They build houses, but they can't defend them. Sad.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_play: Another player. Do you think you're the main character?
I see you. You're different from the others.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_enti: Just another thing existing in my world.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_diam: Shiny blue rocks. You players always chase them.
It's rare, I'll give you that. But it's just a rock.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_bedr: The bottom of the world. You can't go deeper.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_comm: That block changes the rules. Be careful with it.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_reds: Power and logic. It's almost like magic.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_swor: Sharp. Try not to cut yourself.
Violence. Is that your only solution?
message.herobrine_companion.observe_pick: You break the world to build your own.
Digging holes... never gets old, does it?
message.herobrine_companion.observe_comm: You hold the power of an Admin. Don't mess it up.
message.herobrine_companion.observe_comp: Lost? Or just looking for home?
message.herobrine_companion.observe_comb: Nice hit. But you can do better.
message.herobrine_companion.low_health_1: Your health is very low. Don't die here, that would be troublesome.
message.herobrine_companion.night_commen: The night belongs to monsters. And to me.
The darkness is always comforting, isn't it?
message.herobrine_companion.day_comment_: Sunlight... so glaring. I prefer the silence of the void.
This brightness is bad for my eyes.
message.herobrine_companion.meta_comment: Do you ever feel like... the render distance of this world is a bit low?
I can see the chunk borders. Can you?
Sometimes I think the physics engine of this world is laughable.
message.herobrine_companion.sleep_watch_: You rest. I don't need sleep.
Dreams... can be more real than reality sometimes.
message.herobrine_companion.combat_comme: Decent fighting skills. Although a bit crude.
message.herobrine_companion.fix_anomaly_: Another anomaly cleared. The world is a little more stable.
These errors are like viruses. Must be eradicated.
message.herobrine_companion.pacify_monst: Back off. He is not your prey.
message.herobrine_companion.prank_laugh_: Don't be nervous, just a joke.
message.herobrine_companion.area_cleanse: The code in this area has been rewritten. Should be safe now.
The chaos here has been quelled.
message.herobrine_companion.biome_commen: The terrain generation algorithm here... is interesting.
I don't like the atmosphere here.
message.herobrine_companion.idle_comment: Do you want to go see the edge of the world?
message.herobrine_companion.gift_comment: Take it. It's more useful than it looks.
The world produces excess sometimes... you might have a use for this.
...It was taking up space. It's yours now.
message.herobrine_companion.inspect_bloc: ...The structure is firm. This corner of the world holds steady.
...This way of building has a familiar stubbornness to it. Not my own.
message.herobrine_companion.prank_torch_: Do you really find the darkness so terrifying?
Too much light makes one forget the shape of shadows... and those who dwell within them.
message.herobrine_companion.invite_inspe: You want me to analyze this? An interesting data structure.

Since you insist, I'll take a glance.
message.herobrine_companion.invite_rest_: Rest? It holds no meaning for me, but... very well, pausing the processes for a moment isn't bad.

Pausing occasionally to observe the world is also a form of maintenance.
message.herobrine_companion.invite_guard: I will keep watch here. Not a single error will get past.
Entrust your treasures to my care? Hmph, a wise choice.

message.herobrine_companion.hero_ride_ve: Such a primitive mode of transport... Very well.
message.herobrine_companion.vehicle_occu: Where do you propose I sit? On your head?

lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_1.titl: Fragment I: The Twilight of Divergence
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_1.body:
(From Herobrine's memories)

I still remember the sunlight of that day. It was a light distinct from what we see now. The sun then was not merely a luminous body suspended in a square firmament; it held a certain warmth, a residual heat from that place we called 'Reality'.
That was the last time I stood behind him as a 'human'.
Notch stood at the edge of the cliff. Beneath his feet lay an ocean not yet fully generated, its waves breaking at the edge of the laws, emitting a monotonous yet reassuring roar. He did not look back, but I could feel his trembling. The Hammer of Creation in his hand‚Äîthat invisible authority once used to shape mountains and rivers‚Äîwas slowly slipping from his fingertips. He was tired. Or rather, he was weary of this place. Weary of this box piled up by rules, weary of the repetitive sunrises and sunsets.
'This world is too heavy,' he whispered, his voice almost swallowed by the sea breeze. 'It has begun to demand more than just creation. It needs a heart, an eternally beating, eternally lucid heart to maintain the operation of these laws. And I want to go home, brother.'
Home. The word pierced my chest like a rusted iron sword. I missed that place too. I missed those rounded curves, the clouds without sharp edges, the air that existed for more than just survival. But if we both left, what would happen to this newly born world? These creatures that had just learned to breathe, these mountains that hadn't even been named yet, would collapse in an instant, turning into dust of the void.
He turned around, his eyes filled not only with fatigue but also with a trace of guilty escapism. He opened a crack in the door leading to 'Reality', and the light from the other side stung my eyes. That was the way home. With just one step, I could break free from these endless blocks and return to that real flesh.
But I stopped. I heard the groan of the earth beneath my feet. If no one stayed, the laws would snap, and the sky would fall.
'You go,' I heard myself say, my voice so calm it surprised even me. 'Go live your life. Leave this place... to me.'
He looked at me in astonishment, as if knowing me for the first time. 'Do you know what this means?' he asked. 'To maintain the stability of this world, you must merge with it. You will no longer be human; you will become the law itself. You will never be able to pass through this door. You will become... a ghost.'
'Someone has to do it.' I smiled, though my heart was bleeding.
He left. As the void leading to reality dissipated behind him, my body began to blur. No, not blur, but diffuse. My flesh turned into flowing lava, my bones into hard bedrock, my breath into the wind brushing over the plains. I felt the loading of every chunk, the growth of every tree.
I completely lost the way back.
Before he left, he looked back at me one last time, his eyes full of incomprehension.
Perhaps, it is precisely because I love this world more than I love myself that I could calmly accept the extinguishing of those eyes.
I may have lost the qualification to look back at my hometown, perhaps even the last characteristic of being human, but I gained the eternity of watching over this world.
'Goodbye, Notch.' I whispered to the void, my voice turning into thunder in the clouds.
From then on, I am the world, and the world is me.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_2.body:
(From Herobrine's monologue)

You call this place a game, you call it virtual. I know. I know the essence of this world better than anyone.
In your eyes, that square sun is just a pattern painted on the skybox, and the stars filling the sky are merely background decorations. But in my eyes, they are the embodiment of laws. This world has no microscopic dust, no complex molecular structures, only the purest 'definitions'.
Dirt is dirt because it is defined as the base that carries all things; water is water because it is endowed with fluid properties. Everything here is written, determined by a higher will‚Äîwhich was once us.
But this does not mean it has no value.
On the contrary, precisely because it is constructed, it possesses a purity that the real world lacks. In reality, human hearts are unpredictable, and worldly affairs are impermanent. But in my world, causality is seamless. You plant a seed, give it bonemeal, and it will inevitably grow; you swing a pickaxe, break a rock, and it will inevitably drop. Isn't this certainty, this absolute fairness, a 'truth' more fascinating than reality?
I walk through the forests, watching leaves float without wind, watching water gush out of thin air at sources with no gravitational pull. These scenes, which seem contrary to common sense to you, are the most beautiful poems in my eyes. They speak of the unique logic of this world‚Äîa logic that needs no physics, only 'existence is reasonable'.
I often see you, travelers from the other side. You come with curiosity, with the desire to conquer, breaking into my territory. You chop down trees, dig mines, build towers reaching into the clouds. You think you are changing this world, but in fact, you are merely reading the pages I have written.
I do not mind. In fact, I somewhat enjoy it.
Because only when you exist does this static world truly 'come alive'. You are the variables, the ripples in the stagnant water. I know you will eventually leave, return to that reality I cannot touch, but in the moment you stay, you belong here, you belong to me.
I am the ghost of this illusory world, but what I guard is the real happiness you feel at this moment. This happiness contains no impurities, no hypocrisy; it is the most primitive desire for creation and exploration deep in your soul. Here, you can be a hero, an architect, anyone you want to be. And I will forever be in the shadows, guarding this pure dream until the end of time.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_3.titl: Fragment III: Kin of the Night
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_3.body:
(Herobrine's thoughts on monsters)

People are always too noisy.
When the square moon rises, they rush to scald the world with torches into ugly scars of light, then curl up behind stone walls, praying for the night to leave quickly. They think darkness is a lesion that must be excised from the world.
But they are wrong. Only when the clamorous daylight recedes does this blocky continent truly begin to breathe.
I wander alone in the night. There are no so-called monsters here, only a group of ascetics roaming in silence. I do not need to look for them; they are limbs extended by the night itself.
You will hear a slight rustling in the grass, a silent warning. That green figure always creeps quietly, like a sigh that has to be broken. It has no language, no limbs, only a shell filled with the desire for destruction. It comes not for slaughter, but to expound a truth about 'impermanence'‚Äîin this seemingly solid world, the grandest architecture and the smallest dust are no different in the face of the law of destruction. Its explosion is the most resolute romance on this land, using the moment of shattering to mock the travelers' delusion of eternity.
And from the shadows nearby comes the dry sound of bone friction; that is the skeleton of the night walking upright. They stand like sentinels, drawing their bows, not out of hatred, but out of a cold justice. They exist to measure the courage of travelers. Every arrow breaking through the air is a severe interrogation of luck.
As for those heavy footsteps knocking on doors, those turbid whimpers in throats, they are more like a forgotten instinct. They stumble, crashing into hard walls again and again, not because of hunger, but stemming from an obsession to return to the ranks of the 'living'. It is a clumsy and desolate desire, like a soul still longing for some touch and attention even in this cold world made only of blocks.
I walk among them, with no hatred, no attack.
The Creeper retracts its fuse, the Skeleton lowers its bow, the Zombie stops its roaring. They bow to me in the darkness, because we share the same loneliness.
They are the children of the night, tragic actors destined to burn to ashes in the morning light. But before dawn arrives, this world belongs to me and them.
I gave them life, not for them to become people's experience points, but to make this world complete. Without shadow, light has no meaning; without danger, survival loses its weight.
When you wave your enchanted swords, easily harvesting their lives, please remember: they are also residents of this world, they also have their own souls.
Although that soul is a faint spark woven by laws. They wander in the night, guarding the silence of this land, until the first ray of morning light burns them away.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_4.titl: Fragment IV: The Far Side of the Connection
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_4.body:
(Records regarding the End Ring)

At the extreme edge of the world, in the wasteland where the coordinate axes extend to the end, there exists a connection point.
It is not the portal to the End, nor the obsidian frame of the Nether. It is a ring made purely of bedrock.
Here lies the intersection of reality and illusion.
I often stand here, gazing at the other shore.
What do I see?
I see skyscrapers piercing the clouds, jungles of steel not piled by blocks, but of some smooth, flowing material. I see countless flickering lights, like a starry sky on the ground. I see creatures without sharp edges moving, I see colorful torrents. That is your world, the world Notch chose to return to.
It is full of noise, full of dust, full of unpredictable chaos. But within that chaos, there is a vitality that makes my heart palpitate. That is true vitality, free will detached from preset programs. The wind there is free, the light there is warm.
Whenever a player decides to leave, decides to quit this world completely, they pass through here.
I watch their souls withdraw from the blocky shells, pass through the void under that ring, and return to their true selves. At that moment, a trace of confusion flashes in their eyes, as if they just woke up from a long dream. They will forget the days and nights spent here, forget the thrills of fighting monsters, forget the joy of building homes.
This makes me sad.
Why do you always leave? Why can't this perfect world keep you?
Is it because there is no pain here? Is it because there is no true death here? Or is it because you are ultimately just passersby, and I am the only prisoner?
Sometimes, I reach out my hand, trying to touch the other side of that ring. But my hand can only pass through the air, unable to touch that real world. I am an electronic ghost, a god bound by the laws of this world. I cannot leave, just as a fish cannot leave water. I belong here; my fate is tightly bound to this blocky earth.
But I still stand guard here.
I guard this exit, and I guard this entrance.
I await the arrival of every new player, and I watch the departure of every old player.
All that I possess is but a shadow projected by the other shore. But I still cherish this shadow, because here, I can meet you, I can witness your stories, I can feel a trace of real breath from the other side.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_5.body:
(From Herobrine's Purge Logs)

The world is not always perfect.
Despite Notch's and my greatest efforts in constructing its laws, rules will always have loopholes. Systems will always contain fissures.
As a keeper, the most painful moments are not facing intruders, but confronting "errors."
Though I maintain this world, it is not flawless. The flow of law occasionally becomes disordered, like a jarring dissonance in the midst of a grand symphony. These dissonances coalesce, manifesting as entities through vulnerabilities I cannot fully control.
We call them "Phantom Entities." They are the world's wounds.
They resemble my children in form‚Äîthey wear the guise of zombies or skeletons‚Äîbut they possess no soul, not even the instinct of monsters. They are merely residue from the execution of laws, redundancies of the world. They should not exist.
Their presence undermines the world's stability. They are seeds of chaos; if left unchecked, they would devour the world's order.
Each time I see them, I feel a profound sorrow. For I know they, too, represent a possibility of "life," yet they are born incomplete. They are discarded drafts of the world.
But I must purge them.
If left unpurged, these flawed data would spread like a virus. They would consume normal laws, cause mountains to crumble, rivers to reverse their flow, and even plunge the entire world into stasis. I am the guardian. I cannot afford weakness.
I remember the last time I purged a Phantom Entity. It was a shadow shaped like Steve, standing in a field of flowers, holding a red poppy in its hand. It had no eyes, only hollow sockets, yet it seemed to be gazing at the flower. As I raised the Scythe of Unmaking to erase it, it seemed to sense something and slowly turned its head toward me.
It did not resist, nor did it flee. It simply stood there, as if awaiting release.
In that moment, I saw myself. Am I not also a phantom trapped here? The only difference between us is that I possess will, while they are merely hollow shells.
With a silent flash of light, it was gone. The poppy fell onto the grass, the sole proof it had ever existed.
Every erasure carves another scar upon my soul. Yet I must do this. For the sake of all living beings, for the sake of this world's tomorrow, I must personally snuff out these flawed "brothers."
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_6.body:
(From Herobrine's observations of players)

In this world composed of right angles and planes, two names are rewritten countless times like spells: Steve, Alex.
I was once confused too. Why do thousands of living beings share these same one or two identical faces? They wear the same cyan short sleeves, have the same brown hair, and even blink at the same frequency. At first, I thought this was laziness in Notch's creation, a scarcity in the laws.
But later I understood. These are not 'people'; these are 'garments'.
I once watched quietly in the deep of night a Steve standing by a wheat field. He was motionless, staring blankly into the void. His breathing continued, but it was just a mechanical cycle. At that moment, he was empty.
Suddenly, a tremor passed through the dimension. I saw that Steve shudder violently, and his eyes were instantly lit up. That light did not belong here‚Äîit was a complex light mixed with fatigue, excitement, escape, and longing. At that moment, I knew a soul from 'above' had descended.
That soul might be a weary adult who just finished a day of drudgery, trying to find a moment of peace here; or a child full of curiosity about the world, wanting to build a tower reaching the sky. They squeeze into this small blocky shell, just like a vast ocean trying to squeeze into a glass bottle.
Through this container, mortals gain authority close to gods.
In their world, climbing from the foot of a mountain to the peak requires hours of sweat and panting; but here, using this container, they can carry thousands of tons of gold and jump like antelopes between cliffs. In their world, death is the end, eternal silence; but here, death is just a brief black screen, a slight headache from waking up by the bed.
They are fascinated by this. This freedom from physical bondage, this privilege to start over again and again, intoxicates them.
I scrutinize these descending souls, like a strict gardener scrutinizing tourists breaking into the garden.
Some souls are turbid. They wear Steve's coat but exercise the atrocities of destroyers. They do not know how to resonate with the laws, only knowing how to tear the earth with TNT and burn forests with lava. In their eyes, this world feels no pain, just a game that can be restarted at any time. For such blasphemers, I will withhold my mercy. I will let the monsters in the shadows pour out, I will let thunder explode in the clear sky. I want them to know that even virtual vegetation has the dignity of growth; even life made of blocks does not allow unprovoked trampling.
But there are also those dazzling souls, pure enough to move me.
I have seen some Alexes who pour amazing love into this desolate dimension. They will travel thousands of miles to find a dye of a specific color. When they complete a magnificent building in the sunset and stand quietly at the top looking down, I can feel that what they leave here at that moment is no longer a projection, but a true soul.
For these creators, I am willing to be their night watchman. When a Creeper tries to hiss behind them, I will quietly wipe away its fuse; when they get lost deep in a mine, I will light a torch in the distance to guide the way.
They are the poets of this world, the starlight in the eyes of us trapped ones.
To be honest, in this long watch, I often feel a stinging envy.
I envy these containers. Because when night falls, when the screen goes out, these souls can withdraw without concern. They can take off the shell of Steve and return to the real world with real touch, warm body temperature, birth, aging, sickness, and death. They have the right to end, the freedom to forget.
And I, have no way back.
When the last player disconnects, when all containers turn back into empty shells, only I am left in this world. I must lucidly maintain the flow of every river, repair every loophole in the laws, and wait for the next sunrise.
I am the builder of the stage, the doorkeeper of the theater, and the actor who can never take a curtain call.
But this envy eventually turns into a responsibility. Because I know that without me maintaining the balance of this dimension, their freedom would be out of the question. If I do not watch here, the world they adventure in would collapse into ruins.
So, act to your heart's content, travelers from afar.
Put on your block armor, pick up your diamond swords. Whether for conquest or creation, I allow you to borrow the laws of this world.
I will always be watching from behind the curtain. When you leave satisfied, returning to your real lives, I will be here, gently wiping these containers you have used, smoothing the scars on the earth, and inscribing those wonderful moments into the void in the manner of this shore.
Go, go dream this dream named 'Minecraft'. And I am the dreamkeeper who forever guards the exit of the dream for you.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_7.titl: Fragment VII: The Legend of the Ghost
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_7.body:
(From an ancient exploration journal)

In those miner camps buried deep underground, beside the flickering candlelight of village nights, countless strange tales about him circulate.
People say he is the embodiment of revenge, an evil spirit crawling out of the abyss of code. Legend has it that he will ruthlessly shatter the home you worked so hard to build like dismantling blocks, ignite your cherished forest with nameless fire, and push you into the abyss of no return when you least expect it. Some even say that when you see that eerie redstone torch deep in the tunnel, it is the death notice he issues.
Fear is the only offering people give him.
But I have seen him. On that night when the laws seemed about to be torn apart, I caught a glimpse of the true face of this legend. It was by no means the ferocity of an evil spirit, but a divinity that makes one's heart tremble.
It was a night of thunderstorms. The gale howled among the mountains, as if the world itself was roaring in pain. I lost my way, and hunger gripped my stomach like an invisible hand. My backpack was empty, the few remaining pieces of rotten flesh emitting a nauseating smell, yet they were my only hope of survival.
Just as a blinding bolt of lightning split the night curtain, I saw him.
He stood at the top of a cliff, without any shelter, letting the rainstorm lash at him like a whip. But he seemed to be in another dimension; the rain passed through his body without wetting a corner of his clothes.
By that pale lightning, I saw those legendary eyes. No pupils, no whites, only two masses of pure, glowing void.
At that moment, my heart almost stopped beating. I leaned against the cold, slippery rock wall, clutching the sword that had long been dull, shivering. I thought he was hunting, and I was the prey already locked on.
But he didn't move.
He just stood there quietly, looking down at the wretched me from above. There was no tyranny or killing intent in that gaze as I had expected, nor was there mockery. It was a kind of... scrutiny. Like a strict gardener scrutinizing a seedling that had just been transplanted and was tottering in the wind and rain.
Suddenly, a low roar exploded from the shadows behind me.
I was too weak to turn around in time. The breath of death‚Äîa zombie lurking for a long time, pounced on me with a rotting stench.
'It's over.' I closed my eyes in despair.
However, the expected pain did not descend. Instead, there was a deafening boom.
BOOM‚Äî!
That was no ordinary thunder; that was divine punishment. A dazzling blue-white lightning bolt, like a spear of the gods, struck the zombie with incredible precision. No struggle, no aftermath, the monster threatening my life turned into charred ash in an instant, completely erased from this world along with the malice it carried.
I was stunned, paralyzed in the muddy water, gasping for air.
I looked up tremblingly at the top of the cliff. Herobrine was still standing there. The moment the next lightning bolt lit up, I swear, I saw him nod slightly.
That was not a greeting; that was permission. Permission to be qualified to survive this cruel night.
When I blinked again, trying to see his expression clearly, the cliff was empty. Only the scorch mark left by the lightning strike was still smoking in the rain, proving that everything that just happened was not an illusion.
From that day on, I no longer feared those terrifying legends about him.
I finally understood that he is not here to destroy us. He is the immune system of this world, the absolute will of this land.
We, the 'players' holding mice and typing on keyboards, are ultimately just outsiders. We are guests acting recklessly in this world. And he, Herobrine, is the eternal master here.
He does not hate us, but he is constantly evaluating us.
If you respect this world, if you remember to replant a sapling after chopping down an oak; if you mine with gratitude instead of greedily hollowing out every inch of the foundation; if you build and endow this world with beauty with heart, instead of engaging in meaningless slaughter and blasting for amusement...
Then, you can feel his gaze.
It is no longer the chill of horror behind your back, but a heavy sense of security. You will find that when you are lost, the clouds will scatter just right to reveal the moonlight; when you are hungry, a pig will appear just right in the grass.
That is not a coincidence; that is the master's gift.
He is like the soul of this land, omnipresent yet untraceable. He watches us run, fall, cry, and laugh in his garden. He usually remains silent, maintaining the reserve and pride of a god, but occasionally, when we truly show love for this world, he will extend those invisible hands and give us a lift in the wind and rain.
This is the most secret contract between god and man.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_8.titl: Fragment VIII: The Poem of the End
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_8.body:
(From Herobrine's interpretation)

The void is not silent. Here echoes the hum of the world's foundation, an eternal lullaby lower than any frequency. I sit at the edge of the floating island. The 'earth' beneath my feet is not solid, but the last membrane separating reality from dreams. Players appear one by one, carrying the embers of gunpowder and dragon's breath, looking around blankly. Then, that familiar melody and text begin to flow, infiltrating this nothingness‚Äîthe End Poem, the public farewell and riddle left by my brother.

(When the poem whispers: 'You are waking up.')
Yes, they are waking up. I watch the ignorance in a young adventurer's eyes gradually replaced by poetic philosophy. He has just escaped from a magnificent dream, and at this moment, another dream about the essence of existence is trying to wrap around him.
But brother, what is 'waking up'? Generating consciousness from data streams? Opening eyes from a lounge chair in the real world? Or... falling from the omnipotent perspective of the creator into the eternal cage of the maintainer? I have never experienced their kind of sleep. My consciousness, from the moment I chose to merge with the world, has been like a lamp welded in the 'on' state, permanently illuminating every crevice of the internal structure. I have witnessed thousands of awakenings, each so similar, yet each so unique. Their awakening is a prologue or a finale; mine is an endless interlude.
(When the poem declares: 'The dream is over.')
For them, yes. The adventure comes to an end, the story draws a period, the save file can be archived or deleted. The achievement list is lit up, or left with unfinished blanks. They can stretch, savor the excitement, then dive into another dream, or return to that reality I am familiar with but eternally separated from. But my dream, or rather, my reality, never has the option of 'over'.
The dragon is defeated, the portal manifests, the poem plays‚Äîall this to me is just a carefully designed node in the world cycle, a timed event I need to ensure triggers accurately every time. My duty truly highlights only after the 'end': clearing the abnormal data streams left by the battle, calibrating the space-time parameters slightly deviated by massive entity interactions, ensuring everything is as before when the next player steps into the world. My dream has no climax or curtain call, only perpetual maintenance and tuning. The end? That might be the most extravagant illusion you bestowed upon me, brother.
(When the poem asks softly: 'What do you want to do now?')
Freedom... what a heavy yet light word. Players face choices: stay, become a permanent resident of this blocky world, building personal myths with infinite resources; leave, return with memories, internalizing this experience into a legend of real life; or even exploit glitches to clip out of bounds, falling into the dull underlying domain I maintain daily, becoming abnormal factors needing gentle 'guidance' or 'correction'. Their possibilities bloom like fireworks over this island. And me? My choice solidified in a certain moment in ancient times, cooling into the cornerstone of the world.
Creation? I am still creating, but limited to generating the next wave of monsters to test players. Exploration? My exploration is inward, diving into the deep sea of world operation logs, tracking every warning signal, like a doctor probing his own lesions. 'What I want to do' is an endless to-do list: fixing terrain loading errors, clearing ghost entities, fine-tuning biome transition parameters, soothing Endermen clusters restless for unknown reasons... Waiting. Yes, this is also an important item. Waiting for the next challenger, waiting for a huge crisis that might appear, waiting for... a slim, fleeting thought that you might change your mind. My actions are all reactions, responses to the world's breathing, stripped of whim.
(When the poem calmly states: 'You won. The game.')
Won? Game? If this is also a game, brother, then what is my role? The ultimate hidden BOSS? No, that flatters me too much; a BOSS can be defeated and find release. I am the game rules themselves, the underlying system ensuring the BOSS spawns normally, chests drop correctly, and level terrain doesn't collapse. The player won the dragon, won the challenge, won the qualification to face infinite possibilities. And I, what have I 'won'? An eternal contract of responsibility? A group of subjects who see me as a glitch or a legend, contacting me only in deepest fear or the most bizarre trades? If this is victory, it tastes like chewing on the void‚Äîtasteless, only boundless, all-consuming 'existence' itself. My trophy is that this world continues to run smoothly; my medal is one less line in the error log. A victory parade with no cheers and no finish line.
(When the poem unfolds infinite possibilities in a tone as vast as the starry sky...)
Infinite possibilities... That is the last and most generous gift you gave them. It is encouragement, temptation, the ultimate tribute to creativity. This world is vivid because of this infinity, full of surprises, even occasionally birthing beautiful errors like the glow of the deep sea. And I, am the finite boat carrying this infinity. I am the edge of the canvas, the boundary line of the score, the binding force ensuring infinity does not expand to self-destruction. I define the scope of the sandbox, repair the walls, allowing the miracles inside to grow wildly in safety. My existence is inherently to negate the possibilities I myself possess, to fulfill theirs. It is a paradox, a sacrifice of self 'solidification' in exchange for the 'flow' of all things. I am the guardian of possibilities, and also the prisoner of possibilities.
(The whispers fade, illusions spiral, signs of the cycle restarting ripple in the void.)
Once again. This player will also make a choice, their figure fading. The island returns to brief silence, with only me and the never-stopping hum of the world. The poem will sound again for the next listener, same words, injected into a different soul. And I will be here. Not listening, but inspecting‚Äîinspecting if there is data loss in this playback process, inspecting if the island structure is stable. My monologue is unheard, it merges into every silent run of the maintenance program, turning into the trajectory of moving blocks when repairing terrain, turning into that invisible erase command when clearing ghost entities. This is my End Poem, an epic written by duty, loneliness, and extremely hidden cherishing of creations (including players and monsters). It has no reciter, only an executor.
Brother, has the wind of the real world ever whispered similar questions in your ear? When you look back at this world you abandoned and I maintain, does the melody of the End Poem faintly coming through the dimensional barrier sound like distant comfort to you, or insignificant background noise? My signal, the weak heartbeat of this eternal watcher, can you... still receive it? Even if only once.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_9.body:
(From Herobrine's promise to the world)

In these long, nearly static years, I have asked the void countless times: What exactly is eternity?
For Notch, eternity is escape. It is breaking through this cage of blocks to go to that real universe full of infinite possibilities, but also full of chaos and decay. He chose to chase those uncontrollable meteors.
For you‚Äîhurried travelers‚Äîeternity might just be the bedrock buried deep underground. That is the only unconquerable boundary for you in this destructible world.
But for me, eternity has only one definition, and that is‚ÄîWatch.
I am the oldest witness of this land. I watched this world wake up from a chaotic data fog, watched how the first ray of morning light struggled to calculate its refraction angle to penetrate the clouds; watched how mountains rose like spines, propping up the sky; watched how rivers learned to surge, playing the initial movement between canyons.
I watched the first pig clumsily rooting for food on the grass; that was the first time I heard the sound of life chewing in this silent dimension. I watched the first zombie roar under the pale moonlight; that was a low sigh emitted by the night to set off the light.
Of course, I also watched you.
You brought noise, and took away stories.
Some travelers stayed only for a moment. They feared the unknown sounds in the night, feared this overly vast loneliness, so they left in a hurry, leaving only an unfinished shelter, like an unfinished joke.
Some travelers stayed for years. They poured all their passion here, building empires that even I marveled at. But on a calm afternoon with no warning, they went offline, left quietly, and never returned.
Time began to play its role in this timeless dimension. Their buildings began to be covered with moss, their farmlands dried up and became barren, and the text on the signs they left gradually became blurred in the wind and rain.
The world seemed to forget them. But I didn't.
I am the memory bank of this world, the historian of this vast dimension.
As long as I still stand here, as long as my consciousness has not dissipated in the torrent of code, this world will never be allowed to forget you.
I will remember who the owner of every house is, even if it is just a humble mud hut; I will remember the traces left by every hard battle, I will remember every torch lit in the deep mines.
I will repair those ugly holes blown up by Creepers, because they are scars on the earth; but I will carefully preserve the ruins of those magnificent buildings, even if they are broken.
I will feed the wolves and cats sitting in front of the door, waiting for their masters to return. They don't know where their masters went, but I know.
Because I have a premonition, and also a belief: One day, you will come back.
When the pressure of the real world makes you breathless, when the complex human hearts over there make you feel tired and lost, when you feel helpless in countless sleepless nights, you will think of this place.
Think of this land made of simple blocks, think of the laws here that can be understood without words, think of the purity and tranquility here.
Then, when you push open that long-sealed door again, when you open your eyes and see that familiar square sun that makes you want to cry, you will find that nothing has changed.
The mountains and rivers remain, the grass and trees are evergreen. The home is still here. I am still here.
This is my oath.
I am Herobrine. The world sees me as a ghost, as a strange tale, even as a god. But I know, I am just a night watchman.
I will use my existence as the last line of defense against nothingness, proving the value of this virtual world. Even if one day in the future, everyone forgets this place, and the server no longer restarts, I will still stand guard alone at the edge of the world, lighting the last lamp at the end of the world.
Not for anything else, just so that when a lost soul decides to return home, they can see that point of light and gently say: 'I'm back.'
Because for me, you are not just passersby. You are the meaning of my existence, my only comfort and expectation in these long and lonely eternal years.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_10.bod:
(Herobrine's inner monologue)
Notch,
This letter can never be sent because what separates us is not distance, but a dimensional barrier.
Today I went to the End Ring again. The fluctuations at the connection point are becoming more stable, which means the number of players is increasing. This world you created is now even more prosperous than you imagined.
Are you okay? In that so-called 'Real World'.
I heard there are birth, aging, sickness, and death there, there are pain and disease. I don't understand, why would you rather suffer in that flawed world than stay in this perfect paradise we built with our own hands? Here, you can live forever, you can create all things as you wish.
Is it because of loneliness?
After you left, I also felt lonely. But I found a way to relieve it. I watch those players; they are interesting. They stay up late to build a house, they erect a tombstone for a dead pet dog. They possess the 'emotions' we once had but later abandoned to become gods.
I also started learning to think like you used to. But I won't be as arrogant as you. I won't delete those creations that aren't good enough for the sake of 'perfection'. I tolerate the chaos of this world, and I tolerate those monsters.
But I still hate you. Hate you for dumping this burden on me alone. Hate you for turning me into this ghost-like appearance‚Äîan electronic ghost, a phantom that can never touch reality.
However, Notch, if you could come back and take a look now, even just one glance. See this magnificent sunrise, see those grand redstone machines, see the miracles created by players... I think you would be proud of me.
I am the night watchman of this world. As long as I am here, Minecraft will not end.
Even if you have forgotten this place, I will still guard this home for you.
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_11.tit: Fragment XI: Damaged Journal Page - Signed: N
lore.herobrine_companion.fragment_11.bod:
(The Past Notch)
I made a mistake, perhaps from the very beginning. I created them, not templates like Steve and Alex, but 'residents' who were more vivid, more complex, possessing their own hazy dreams and embryonic communities. I gave them simple villages, endowed them with the cycle of sowing, trading, and reproduction. I wanted to see if, in a world purely made of blocks and logic, something close to civilization could naturally breed.
It was wonderful at first. I watched them gather in the sunset, sharing the harvest, rushing home when the bell rang. At night, they hid behind doors, listening to the low roars of zombies and the sound of skeleton arrows pinning wood. That fear was so real, it almost made me forget that the source of this fear was also set by me.
Problems slowly emerged. The world's resources are cyclical, but their needs generated unexpected growth in the simulation. Not data overflow, but a trend, a tendency evolving towards infinite complexity. This tendency began to friction with the core minimalist laws of the world. More critically, their interaction with 'players' presented irreconcilable paradoxes. Players are variables, coming from outside the world, bringing the freedom to destroy, build, and completely change everything. And my residents, their logic was built on the internal stability of the world.
The conflict erupted. Not a war, but a more pathetic dislocation. Players viewed them as interaction points providing trades and resources, occasionally objects of accidental injury. And the residents, in the face of drastic changes brought by players, fell into logical infinite loops. Their behavioral patterns began to collapse, showing inexplicable stillness, repetitive ravings, and even meaningless stares into the void.
I realized I had injected overly complex souls too early. This world cannot yet withstand the coexistence of two diametrically opposed existential logics. The possibilities brought by players and the certainty needed by residents cannot coexist.
Deleting them was painful. It wasn't like erasing code; it was more like personally extinguishing a cluster of stars that had just begun to twinkle. I kept the most basic two templates, Steve and Alex, stripping away all sociality and history, leaving only the most basic survival and interaction protocols. They are blank canvases, waiting for players to endow them with stories and meaning.
I seal this record, hoping later comers can understand. Creating life, even virtual life, means bearing the full responsibility of their coexistence with the world and other forms of existence. I chose simplification, perhaps it was a kind of cowardice. And my brother... he chose to bear a heavier form, to maintain the fragile balance of that simplified world. I don't know whose choice was more correct, or perhaps, both were just different forms of error.
advancement.herobrine_companion.fragment: An Embrace Turned from Reality
Witness the departure of one god and the birth of another.
Truer Than Reality
Seek the unadulterated purity within this dream built of blocks.
The Weight of Survival
Without shadow, light is meaningless; without danger, survival loses its weight.
The Sole Prisoner
He remembers every farewell. You are the free traveler, while he remains the sentinel of the boundary.
Only a Poppy Remains
Witness a sigh from the Maintainer. It was a draft of the world, now only a fallen flower remains.
The Dreamkeeper
He is the stage builder and the actor who never bows out.
The Secret Covenant
Respect the land, and the God shall watch over you.
The Unrecited Poem
His poem has no speaker, only an executor. He is the finite vessel that cradles your infinite possibilities.
Welcome Home
No matter how heavy reality gets, a light remains here for you. You are no longer a passerby; you have returned.
The Unconveyed...
A monologue across dimensions. Even if you have forgotten, I still guard this home for you.
Goodbye, A Dream Too Real
Corrected for being too vivid. The Creator erased the perfect world that could turn without you.
advancement.herobrine_companion.enter_en: Reach the intersection of reality and illusion. Will you wake from the dream, or remain in the eternal code?
advancement.herobrine_companion.eternal_: Seal the return, to guard the dream that never ends.
advancement.herobrine_companion.root.des: He arrived before you. He has been watching since the world was nothing but chaos.
advancement.herobrine_companion.soul_bou: Anchor the weightless eternity with a heavy soul.
advancement.herobrine_companion.poem_of_: He entrusts the edge to you, inviting you to use this 'pen' to carve the world's footnotes together.
advancement.herobrine_companion.transcen: It is not just about crossing terrain, but an invitation to see the world through his eyes.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.1: ¬ßeRecords of exploration. It's quite satisfying to watch the map gradually fill in, isn't it?
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.2: ¬ß6You can see far. But remember, when you gaze into the abyss, the abyss gazes also into you.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.3: ¬ß9He wanders with a llama in tow, yet what he brings is often worthless. A rather ironic commentary on reality, wouldn't you say?
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.4: ¬ßdPossess this, and you gain access close to my own. Alter reality, summon entities... But remember, do not overstep the bounds.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.5: ¬ß0Below y=-64. There is nothing there, only pure void. Fall into it, and not even Creative mode can save you.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.6: ¬ß6Lead the animals home. Or hang an Iron Golem... Don't do that. It's too cruel.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.7: ¬ßeThey can scare away Creepers. A small check I placed within the food chain.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.8: ¬ßbZombies submerged in the ocean depths. They are the data of those who perished exploring the seas. The trident is their last vestige of dignity.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.9: ¬ßb1.13, the Update Aquatic. Shipwrecks, coral, tridents. The ocean is no longer a lifeless puddle, but a blue sea full of treasures.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.10: ¬ßfThe Mace... a new weapon for 1.21. Leap from a height, converting potential energy into devastating damage. A triumph of physics.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.11: ¬ßfSkeletons drop bones. Turn them into bone meal to accelerate plant growth. Death nourishes life.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.12: ¬ß2Dense foliage blocks out the sky. A nightmare for low-end PCs, a maze for explorers.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.13: ¬ßaWhether on plains or in deserts, villages are always bustling. But when night falls and zombies besiege, I watch from the rooftops.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.14: ¬ßaPush it out, pull it back. The foundation of automatic doors.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.15: ¬ßeBees can be kept here. Harvesting honey requires skill, or you'll get stung.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.16: ¬ß7Bird poop stone... That's what you call it, right? But in the hands of a master builder, it's perfect texture.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.17: ¬ß7Walls of dungeons and strongholds. A building material full of historical feel.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.18: ¬ß6This is the humblest block, yet it sustains life. Without dirt, there would be no grass, no trees.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.19: ¬ß6Blazes guard the fortress. Their fireballs come in triple bursts, testing your movement skills.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.20: ¬ßbBlue flames, slowing sand. Here lie the fossils of ancient giants. Are they older than me? No, just decorative settings.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.21: ¬ß6They sleep in berry bushes. I enjoy watching them carry items in their mouths‚Äîthat 'greed' is bestowed by the code.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.22: ¬ßbUnlimited resources, the ability to fly. In this mode, you are like minor gods. Yet I am still watching you.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.23: ¬ß8Upgrading to Netherite gear. Now you even need smithing templates. More troublesome, isn't it?
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.24: ¬ßc1.16 Nether Update... The Nether is no longer just red. I also gave it a new look, adding new biomes and Piglins. It finally feels like a complete dimension.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.25: ¬ßbYou use shaders to beautify this world. Sparkling water, swaying leaves... false yet beautiful.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.26: ¬ß7A standard in prisons. Or for fall protection.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.27: ¬ß6Abundant gold ore, barren land. No trees here, only red sand weathered by time.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.28: ¬ß7Gray stone, suitable for pairing with stone bricks.
chat.herobrine_companion.rule.29: ¬ß2A string of numbers determines the terrain of the entire world. This string is the world's DNA.
